hirarchy.name: definite-indefinite-articles
hirarchy.description: Articles mark definiteness (the vs a/an) and agree in gender/number with nouns.

concept.name: neuter-article-lo
concept.description: Lo is a neuter nominaliser used before adjectives/participles to form abstract nouns or to mean 'what/that which'.

hirarchy.name: subjunctive-mood
hirarchy.description: The subjunctive expresses non-factual or non-asserted situations: wishes, doubts, emotions, recommendations, hypothetical or irrealis contexts.

concept.name: subjunctive-adjective-clauses
concept.description: In adjective clauses, the subjunctive is used when the antecedent is unknown, nonexistent, or indefinite.

hirarchy.name: subjunctive-mood
hirarchy.description: The subjunctive expresses non-factual or non-asserted situations: wishes, doubts, emotions, recommendations, hypothetical or irrealis contexts.

concept.name: subjunctive-with-conjunctions
concept.description: Certain subordinating conjunctions always (or often) trigger the subjunctive because they introduce uncertainty, purpose, or contingency (para que, a menos que, en caso de que, antes de que).

hirarchy.name: prepositions-contractions
hirarchy.description: Prepositions link words and create complements; Spanish has fixed prepositions (a, de, en, por, para, con, sin, sobre, entre...). a + el → al; de + el → del.

concept.name: por-vs-para
concept.description: Two prepositions often translated as 'for' with different uses: por for cause, movement through, duration, exchange; para for purpose, destination, deadline, recipient.

hirarchy.name: direct-indirect-object-pronouns
hirarchy.description: Object pronouns replace direct/indirect objects and cliticize before conjugated verbs or attach to infinitives/gerunds/affirmative imperatives.

concept.name: clitic-order-combinations
concept.description: When two clitic pronouns appear, order and phonological adjustments apply.

hirarchy.name: reflexive-pronouns-verbs
hirarchy.description: Reflexive pronouns (me, te, se, nos, os, se) indicate the subject both performs and receives the action (or lexical pronominal verbs).

concept.name: reciprocal-se
concept.description: Reciprocal use of se expresses mutual actions: nos/se with plural subjects.

hirarchy.name: reflexive-pronouns-verbs
hirarchy.description: Reflexive pronouns (me, te, se, nos, os, se) indicate the subject both performs and receives the action (or lexical pronominal verbs).

concept.name: accidental-se
concept.description: Se + indirect object pronoun expresses accidental occurrences where subject 'loses' control: Se me olvidó.

hirarchy.name: reflexive-pronouns-verbs
hirarchy.description: Reflexive pronouns (me, te, se, nos, os, se) indicate the subject both performs and receives the action (or lexical pronominal verbs).

concept.name: impersonal-se
concept.description: Se used to make general statements without specifying the agent: English passive/impersonal 'one/they/people'.

hirarchy.name: indicative-simple-tenses
hirarchy.description: Indicative tenses express factual, real actions with different temporal/aspective distinctions: present, preterite, imperfect, future, conditional.

concept.name: future-tense
concept.description: The simple future is a synthetic future; ir a + infinitive forms a near future/periphrastic future often used in spoken Spanish.

hirarchy.name: indicative-simple-tenses
hirarchy.description: Indicative tenses express factual, real actions with different temporal/aspective distinctions: present, preterite, imperfect, future, conditional.

concept.name: conditional-tense
concept.description: Conditional expresses hypothetical outcomes or politeness; conditional perfect expresses hypothetical actions in the past.

hirarchy.name: clitic-order-combinations
hirarchy.description: When two clitic pronouns appear, order and phonological adjustments apply.

concept.name: se-lo-construction
concept.description: For sequences le + lo/la/los/las the indirect pronoun le/les changes to se to avoid clashing sounds.

hirarchy.name: imperative-commands
hirarchy.description: Imperative mood expresses commands; affirmative and negative forms use different pronoun placement rules and sometimes different forms (e.g., irregulars).

concept.name: negative-imperative-pronoun-placement
concept.description: Affirmative imperatives attach pronouns; negative imperatives place pronouns before the verb.

hirarchy.name: subject-pronouns-pro-drop
hirarchy.description: Spanish subject pronouns (yo, tú, él…) are often optional because verb inflections indicate person and number (pro-drop).

concept.name: usted-vs-tu
concept.description: Choice of usted vs tú signals formality, social distance, or politeness.

hirarchy.name: subject-pronouns-pro-drop
hirarchy.description: Spanish subject pronouns (yo, tú, él…) are often optional because verb inflections indicate person and number (pro-drop).

concept.name: voseo-vosotros-ustedes
concept.description: Regional variants affect pronoun use and verb forms: voseo uses vos, vosotros used in Spain for informal plural you, ustedes used in Latin America for both formal/informal plural you.

hirarchy.name: direct-indirect-object-pronouns
hirarchy.description: Object pronouns replace direct/indirect objects and cliticize before conjugated verbs or attach to infinitives/gerunds/affirmative imperatives.

concept.name: leismo-loismo-laismo
concept.description: Use of le as masculine direct object (le instead of lo) — common in parts of Spain; loísmo/laísmo other regionally marked variants.

hirarchy.name: direct-indirect-object-pronouns
hirarchy.description: Object pronouns replace direct/indirect objects and cliticize before conjugated verbs or attach to infinitives/gerunds/affirmative imperatives.

concept.name: clitic-doubling
concept.description: Some varieties double objects with clitic pronouns plus full noun phrase (Le di a María el libro — Le doubles a María).

hirarchy.name: conjunctions
hirarchy.description: Conjunctions link clauses/phrases; coordinating (y, pero, o) join equals; subordinating introduce dependent clauses (porque, aunque, cuando, si).

concept.name: queismo-dequeismo
concept.description: Variation/error in using que vs de que in subordinate clauses; dequeísmo is inserting de unnecessarily, queísmo dropping necessary de.

hirarchy.name: verbal-periphrasis
hirarchy.description: Periphrastic constructions combine auxiliary verbs and non-finite verb forms to express aspect, obligation, progression, or intention.

concept.name: causative-constructions
concept.description: Hacer and dejar can be used to indicate causing someone to do something or allowing something to happen.

hirarchy.name: ser-vs-estar
hirarchy.description: Two copulas with different uses: ser generally for inherent/permanent characteristics, identity, origin, time; estar for states, locations, and progressive aspect.

concept.name: ser-estar-confusion
concept.description: Addresses the common mistake of incorrectly choosing between 'ser' (for permanent states) and 'estar' (for temporary states/locations).

hirarchy.name: por-vs-para
hirarchy.description: Two prepositions often translated as 'for' with different uses: por for cause, movement through, duration, exchange; para for purpose, destination, deadline, recipient.

concept.name: por-para-confusion
concept.description: Addresses the common difficulty in choosing the correct preposition, as both can translate to 'for' in English.

hirarchy.name: indicative-simple-tenses
hirarchy.description: Indicative tenses express factual, real actions with different temporal/aspective distinctions: present, preterite, imperfect, future, conditional.

concept.name: preterite-imperfect-misuse
concept.description: Addresses the frequent error of using the wrong past tense to describe an action (completed vs. ongoing/habitual).

hirarchy.name: subjunctive-mood
hirarchy.description: The subjunctive expresses non-factual or non-asserted situations: wishes, doubts, emotions, recommendations, hypothetical or irrealis contexts.

concept.name: subjunctive-indicative-misuse
concept.description: Addresses the common mistake of using the indicative mood in clauses that require the subjunctive (e.g., after expressions of doubt, desire).

hirarchy.name: gender-of-nouns
hirarchy.description: Spanish nouns are grammatically masculine or feminine; agreement for articles, adjectives, and some determiners follows noun gender.

concept.name: gender-agreement-error
concept.description: Addresses the common mistake of failing to match the gender of adjectives and articles to the nouns they modify.

hirarchy.name: conditional-tense
hirarchy.description: Conditional expresses hypothetical outcomes or politeness; conditional perfect expresses hypothetical actions in the past.

concept.name: si-clauses
concept.description: Si clauses categorize real/possible/past counterfactual conditions and determine tense combinations.

hirarchy.name: numerals-ordinals
hirarchy.description: Numerals (uno, dos, tres...) and ordinals (primero, segundo...) have agreement and contraction rules; uno becomes un before masculine noun.

concept.name: agreement-measure-expressions
concept.description: Expressions of measurement may treat numerals and unit phrases specially with singular/plural agreement.

hirarchy.name: double-negatives
hirarchy.description: Spanish commonly uses double negatives (negative element + negative verb or pronoun) and this is grammatical (e.g., No veo nada).

concept.name: negative-polarity-items
concept.description: Words like nada, nadie, nunca, jamás, tampoco express negation and interact with no and sentence scope.

hirarchy.name: reported-speech
hirarchy.description: Indirect speech reports what someone said and frequently requires tense/mood changes (backshifting).

concept.name: sequence-of-tenses
concept.description: In subordinate clauses, the tense/mood of verbs depends on the tense/mood of the main clause (backshift rules).
